title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

title: Florida’s Leaders Opposed Climate Aid. Now They’re Depending on It.
abstract: Before Hurricane Ian, the state’s Republican politicians have rejected federal action to cut greenhouse gas emissions and boost climate resilience.
byline: By Christopher Flavelle and Jonathan Weisman

multimedia.caption: Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.
Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.
Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.

title: Meet the Band of TV Animals That’s Talking to Preschoolers About Climate
abstract: There are few books, shows or other tools to help parents and teachers talk to preschoolers about global warming. “Octonauts: Above and Beyond” is one of the first to try.

multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

title: At Long Last, Can Malaria Be Eradicated?
abstract: Two new vaccines may finally turn back an ancient plague. But in unexpected ways, their arrival also complicates the path to ending the disease.
byline: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Kang-Chun Cheng

multimedia.copyright: Kang-Chun Cheng for The New York Times
Kang-Chun Cheng for The New York Times
Kang-Chun Cheng for The New York Times

title: For Autistic Mothers, Breastfeeding Is Complicated
abstract: Mothers with autism, who are less likely than others to breastfeed, have been hit particularly hard by the baby formula shortage.

title: Russia’s Small Nuclear Arms: A Risky Option for Putin and Ukraine Alike
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has 2,000 small nuclear weapons, but their utility on the battlefield may not be worth the longer-term costs.
byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

multimedia.caption: The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.
The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.
The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.

title: Three Ways to Build Back Smarter After Hurricane Ian
abstract: Big storms are becoming more common. That makes it crucial to take climate change into account when rebuilding.

multimedia.caption: Destruction from Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

title: Unearthing Everyday Life at an Ancient Site in Greece
abstract: Excavations in the Peloponnesian village of Iklaina are yielding rich insights into the lives of the Mycenaean civilization’s general population.

multimedia.caption: An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.
An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.
An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.

title: Uganda Races to Contain a Deadly Ebola Outbreak
abstract: The outbreak was caused by the Sudan strain of the virus, which has no approved vaccine or drug treatment. Scientists are now rushing to begin clinical trials in the coming weeks.

multimedia.caption: Members of the Ebola treatment unit this past week at Mubende Regional Referral Hospital in Uganda.
Members of the Ebola treatment unit this past week at Mubende Regional Referral Hospital in Uganda.
Members of the Ebola treatment unit this past week at Mubende Regional Referral Hospital in Uganda.

title: Fentanyl Test Strips Highlight Rift in Nation’s Struggle to Combat Drug Deaths
abstract: Proponents say the ability to check drugs for the presence of lethal fentanyl may save lives. But critics say the strips enable drug use.
byline: By Jan Hoffman and Desiree Rios

title: Price of New A.L.S. Treatment Will Be $158,000 Per Year, Maker Says
abstract: The list price of the therapy, Relyvrio, is much higher than an economic research group recommends, but the company says most patients will pay very little themselves.

multimedia.caption: The new drug, marketed as Relyvrio, has a list price of $158,000 a year.
The new drug, marketed as Relyvrio, has a list price of $158,000 a year.
The new drug, marketed as Relyvrio, has a list price of $158,000 a year.

title: Half of Adults Have Heard Little or Nothing About New Covid Boosters, Survey Finds
abstract: The latest shots, which target Omicron and its subvariants, could offer protection against a winter surge in cases. But many people are unsure if they’re eligible.

multimedia.caption: Preparing a booster shot at a vaccination site in Maywood, Ill., this month.

title: Nick Holonyak Jr., Pioneer of LED Lighting, Is Dead at 93
abstract: He invented a visible red-light diode. His 41 patents also included lasers that enabled DVD and CD players.
des_facet: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

multimedia.caption: Nick Holonyak Jr. in an undated photo. He was among the first scientists to predict that incandescent bulbs and fluorescent lamps would eventually be replaced by light-emitting diodes.
Nick Holonyak Jr. in an undated photo. He was among the first scientists to predict that incandescent bulbs and fluorescent lamps would eventually be replaced by light-emitting diodes.
Nick Holonyak Jr. in an undated photo. He was among the first scientists to predict that incandescent bulbs and fluorescent lamps would eventually be replaced by light-emitting diodes.

title: Can Smartphones Help Predict Suicide?
abstract: A unique research project is tracking hundreds of people at risk for suicide, using data from smartphones and wearable biosensors to identify periods of high danger — and intervene.

multimedia.caption: Katelin Cruz uses a phone and FitBit to submit data about her mood and other metrics to Harvard researchers studying suicidal tendencies. “I think it’s almost easier to tell the truth to a computer,” she said.
multimedia.copyright: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times

title: NASA May Let Billionaire Astronaut and SpaceX Lift Hubble Telescope
abstract: Jared Isaacman, who traveled to orbit on the Inspiration4 mission, is pursuing a private space program in collaboration with Elon Musk’s rocket company.

multimedia.caption: Jared Isaacman under the cupola of a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule during the Inspiration4 mission last year.
Jared Isaacman under the cupola of a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule during the Inspiration4 mission last year.
Jared Isaacman under the cupola of a SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule during the Inspiration4 mission last year.

title: Downpours From Ian Prompt Florida Treatment Plants to Release Waste
abstract: Concern turns to industrial sites and huge farms farther north as the storm heads toward South Carolina.

multimedia.caption: Reservoirs at Piney Point, a phosphate plant in Palmetto, Fla., that is in the process of being shut down.
Reservoirs at Piney Point, a phosphate plant in Palmetto, Fla., that is in the process of being shut down.

title: Leonard Cole, Who Detailed Secret Army Germ Tests, Dies at 89
abstract: A dentist with a parallel career as a political scientist, he drew attention to a program that made millions of Americans unwitting guinea pigs.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Leonard Cole at a House hearing in 2013. He chronicled a secret U.S. Army program that involved spreading bacterial and chemical agents in U.S. cities to test the country’s vulnerability to such attacks.

Leonard Cole at a House hearing in 2013. He chronicled a secret U.S. Army program that involved spreading bacterial and chemical agents in U.S. cities to test the country’s vulnerability to such attacks.

Leonard Cole at a House hearing in 2013. He chronicled a secret U.S. Army program that involved spreading bacterial and chemical agents in U.S. cities to test the country’s vulnerability to such attacks.

title: Methane Might Be a Bigger Climate Problem Than Thought, Study Finds
abstract: Flaring, meant to burn off the planet-warming gas at industrial sites, doesn’t always work as intended, according to researchers.

multimedia.caption: A flare in the Permian Basin in Midland, Texas. Methane is a stronger, though shorter-lived, greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide.
A flare in the Permian Basin in Midland, Texas. Methane is a stronger, though shorter-lived, greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide.
A flare in the Permian Basin in Midland, Texas. Methane is a stronger, though shorter-lived, greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide.

title: Overlooked No More: Maria Orosa, Inventor of Banana Ketchup
abstract: As a food scientist, she sought to reduce the Philippines’ dependence on imported food, pioneering new ways to use local products. And that was before she became a war hero.

multimedia.caption: Maria Orosa, a food scientist and nationalist, sought to make the Philippines less dependent on imported food. Banana ketchup was one result.
Maria Orosa, a food scientist and nationalist, sought to make the Philippines less dependent on imported food. Banana ketchup was one result.
Maria Orosa, a food scientist and nationalist, sought to make the Philippines less dependent on imported food. Banana ketchup was one result.

title: Hurricane Ian’s Toll Is Severe. Lack of Insurance Will Make It Worse.
abstract: In Florida’s hardest-hit counties, fewer than 1 in 5 homes have flood insurance. That means communities will struggle to rebuild, experts warn.

multimedia.caption: A flooded area of Fort Myers, Fla., on Wednesday after Hurricane Ian passed through.
A flooded area of Fort Myers, Fla., on Wednesday after Hurricane Ian passed through.
A flooded area of Fort Myers, Fla., on Wednesday after Hurricane Ian passed through.

title: Hospitals in Coastal Cities Risk Flooding Even in ‘Weak’ Hurricanes, Study Finds
abstract: In a third of the 78 cities examined on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, half or more of hospitals were at risk from a Category 2 storm, the researchers said.

multimedia.caption: Flood barriers were erected in front of Tampa General Hospital in preparation for Hurricane Ian.
multimedia.copyright: Johnny Milano for The New York Times

title: Physician Burnout Has Reached Distressing Levels, New Research Finds
abstract: Nearly two-thirds of doctors are experiencing at least one symptom of burnout, a huge increase from before the pandemic. But the situation is not irreparable, researchers say.

multimedia.caption: Burnout, in medical literature, is defined by increased emotional exhaustion, a more distant approach to the job and a declining sense of personal accomplishment.
Burnout, in medical literature, is defined by increased emotional exhaustion, a more distant approach to the job and a declining sense of personal accomplishment.
Burnout, in medical literature, is defined by increased emotional exhaustion, a more distant approach to the job and a declining sense of personal accomplishment.

title: How McKinsey Got Into the Business of Addiction
abstract: The consulting firm’s work with opioid makers is well known, but for decades McKinsey worked with Big Tobacco and has also advised Juul, the e-cigarette company.
byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe

multimedia.caption: McKinsey & Company in New York City. The firm’s work with opioid makers is well known, but its work with cigarette and vaping companies has escaped public scrutiny.
multimedia.copyright: John Taggart for The New York Times

title: New Infectious Threats Are Coming. The U.S. Probably Won’t Contain Them.
abstract: The coronavirus revealed flaws in the nation’s pandemic plans. The spread of monkeypox shows that the problems remain deeply entrenched.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Flags representing Americans who died of Covid-19, a work by artist Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg, on the National Mall last year.
Flags representing Americans who died of Covid-19, a work by artist Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg, on the National Mall last year.

title: Lasker Award Honors Development of Noninvasive Prenatal DNA Test
abstract: The prestigious medical prizes also recognized the creator of a global Covid dashboard and discoveries of proteins and cell bindings to fight disease.
